verses.text: Look, a man of God came from Judah to Bethel by the word of the LORD, while Jeroboam was standing by the altar to burn incense.
verses.comment: The phrase 'man of God' refers to a prophet. 'By the word of the LORD' indicates prophetic commission.

verses.text: He cried out against the altar by the word of the LORD and said, 'Altar, altar! This is what the LORD says: Look, a son shall be born to the house of David, Josiah by name, and he will sacrifice on you the priests of the high places who burn incense on you, and human bones will be burned on you.'
verses.comment: Josiah is explicitly named centuries in advance; reference to 2 Kings 23:15-18.

verses.text: That same day he gave a sign, saying, 'This is the sign that the LORD has spoken: Look, the altar will be split apart, and the ashes that are on it will be poured out.'
verses.comment: The prophet gives a confirming sign, a common pattern in prophetic encounters.

verses.text: When the king heard the word of the man of God, which he called out against the altar at Bethel, Jeroboam stretched out his hand from the altar, saying, 'Seize him!' But his hand, which he stretched out against him, dried up so he could not pull it back to himself.
verses.comment: 'Dried up' means paralyzed or withered.

verses.text: The altar also was split apart, and the ashes poured out from the altar, according to the sign that the man of God had given by the word of the LORD.
verses.comment: Sign promptly fulfilled—ashes literally poured out, confirming the message.

verses.text: Then the king responded and said to the man of God, 'Please plead with the LORD your God and pray for me, that my hand may be restored.' So the man of God pleaded with the LORD, and the king's hand was restored and became as it was before.
verses.comment: King begs for intercession; prophetic intercession leads to healing.

verses.text: Then the king said to the man of God, 'Come home with me and refresh yourself, and I will give you a reward.'
verses.comment: Offering a meal/reward was a typical gesture of gratitude, often refused by prophets to show their independence from the king.

verses.text: But the man of God said to the king, 'Even if you gave me half your house, I would not go with you, nor would I eat bread or drink water in this place.'
verses.comment: Draws a boundary according to prophetic orders.

verses.text: 'For this is how I was commanded by the word of the LORD: “You shall not eat bread nor drink water, nor return by the way that you came.”'
verses.comment: Prophet forbidden to accept hospitality or return by same route. See Judg. 13:14 for similar Nazarite restriction.

verses.text: So he went another way and did not return by the way that he came to Bethel.
verses.comment: Obedience to God's explicit command.

verses.text: Now there was an old prophet living in Bethel. His sons came and told him all that the man of God had done that day in Bethel. They also told their father the words that he had spoken to the king.
verses.comment: Introduction of a new character—the old prophet of Bethel.

verses.text: Their father said to them, 'Which way did he go?' for his sons had seen the way the man of God went who came from Judah.
verses.comment: The old prophet seeks out the man of God—possibly out of curiosity or jealousy.

verses.text: He said to his sons, 'Saddle the donkey for me.' So they saddled the donkey for him, and he rode on it.
verses.comment: Donkey as standard travel animal.

verses.text: He went after the man of God and found him sitting under an oak tree, and said to him, 'Are you the man of God who came from Judah?' He said, 'I am.'
verses.comment: 'Oak' could also be translated as 'terebinth,' a large, shade-giving tree in Israel.

verses.text: Then he said to him, 'Come home with me and eat bread.'
verses.comment: Similar invitation as the king, but from a prophet.

verses.text: But he said, 'I cannot return with you or go in with you, nor will I eat bread or drink water with you in this place.'
verses.comment: Man of God repeats his prohibition.

verses.text: 'For I was told by the word of the LORD, “You shall not eat bread nor drink water there, nor return by the way that you came.”'
verses.comment: Direct repetition for emphasis.

verses.text: But he said to him, 'I also am a prophet as you are, and an angel spoke to me by the word of the LORD, saying, “Bring him back with you to your house, so that he may eat bread and drink water.”' But he lied to him.
verses.comment: Explicit statement that the old prophet lied.

verses.text: So he went back with him and ate bread in his house and drank water.
verses.comment: Man of God disobeys God's command due to deception.

verses.text: While they were sitting at the table, the word of the LORD came to the prophet who had brought him back,
verses.comment: God uses the lying prophet now to deliver a true prophecy.

verses.text: and he cried out to the man of God who came from Judah, 'This is what the LORD says: Because you have disobeyed the word of the LORD and have not kept the command that the LORD your God gave you,
verses.comment: God's judgment announced for disobedience.

verses.text: 'but came back and ate bread and drank water in the place of which he said to you, “Do not eat bread and do not drink water,” your body will not come to the tomb of your fathers.'
verses.comment: To 'not come to the tomb of your fathers' means denied burial in the family tomb—a sign of disgrace or judgment.

verses.text: After he had eaten bread and drunk, he saddled the donkey for the prophet whom he had brought back.
verses.comment: The 'he' in context is the old prophet.

verses.text: As he went away, a lion met him on the road and killed him. His body was thrown on the road, and the donkey stood beside it; the lion also stood beside the body.
verses.comment: Miraculous sign: lion does not eat the body or donkey, highlighting divine judgment.

verses.text: Some men passed by and saw the body thrown on the road, with the lion standing beside the body. And they went and told it in the city where the old prophet lived.
verses.comment: Public spectacle of judgment.

verses.text: When the prophet who had brought him back from the way heard it, he said, 'It is the man of God, who disobeyed the word of the LORD; therefore the LORD has given him to the lion, which has torn him and killed him, according to the word of the LORD that he spoke to him.'
verses.comment: Recognition of God's judgment as fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: And he said to his sons, 'Saddle the donkey for me.' So they saddled it.
verses.comment: Repeated family cooperation.

verses.text: He went and found his body thrown on the road, with the donkey and the lion standing beside the body. The lion had not eaten the body or torn the donkey.
verses.comment: The unnatural behavior of lion and donkey emphasizes miraculous judgment.

verses.text: So the prophet picked up the body of the man of God and laid it on the donkey, and brought it back. The old prophet came to the city to mourn and to bury him.
verses.comment: Shows a final respect, even after the man of God’s disobedience.

verses.text: He laid his body in his own grave, and they mourned over him, saying, 'Alas, my brother!'
verses.comment: Calling him 'brother' suggests spiritual kinship among prophets.

verses.text: After he had buried him, he said to his sons, 'When I die, bury me in the grave where the man of God is buried; lay my bones beside his bones.'
verses.comment: This command likely expresses solidarity with the prophet's message and hope of blessing.

verses.text: 'For the word will surely come true which he cried out by the word of the LORD against the altar in Bethel and against all the houses of the high places which are in the cities of Samaria.'
verses.comment: Old prophet affirms message’s truth, even if the messenger failed.

verses.text: After this event, Jeroboam did not turn from his evil way, but again made priests of the high places from among all the people. Any who wanted, he ordained to be priests of the high places.
verses.comment: 'Evil way' specifically refers to idolatry. Priests not from Levites.

verses.text: And this thing became a sin to the house of Jeroboam, so as to cut it off and destroy it from the face of the earth.
verses.comment: 'This thing' refers to Jeroboam’s religious innovations, resulting in divine judgment.
